elements.title: Cathie Dunsford (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Cathie Dunsford (pictured) was unable to find many books about lesbianism in the 1970s, but by the 1980s had herself become a writer and anthologist of lesbian literature?

elements.title: Institutes (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 1816, a copy of the long-lost Institutes by the Roman jurist Gaius was discovered, hidden underneath writings by Saint Jerome?

elements.title: Ruth M. Anderson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Ruth M. Anderson recorded a "timeless" Spain in her photographs of the 1920s?

elements.title: King George VI Memorial Chapel (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Queen Elizabeth II wanted the King George VI Memorial Chapel to hold the remains of three British monarchs and their consorts?

elements.title: Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Nasafi (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Nasafi was the first theologian to introduce concepts from Neoplatonism into Isma'ili doctrine?

elements.title: a Nebraska radio station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a Nebraska radio station's plans to broadcast college sports were met with "audible gasps"?

elements.title: Dave Barrow (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Dave Barrow quit municipal politics to work at his family's insurance brokerage before becoming mayor of Richmond Hill?

elements.title: NIMBY Rails (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that there are no NIMBYs in NIMBY Rails?
